page.title: 06Crofting in Aith
page.content: Crofting is very small-scale farming. There are 24 crofts in the area. These crofts are mainly dependent on sheep as most of the land is rough hill grazing though a lot of it is being fenced in, reseeded and improved. The main breeds of sheep are Shetland, Cheviot and Suffolk crosses. The lambs are born late in the spring and sold in late summer. There is a lot of work to be done with lambing, dipping, shearing etc. Only 3 of the crofts keep cattle. The small amount of arable land is used to grow winter feed for animals and produce for home use. The crops grown include hay, potatoes, turnips, corn and cabbage. The use of machinery has increased in the last 20 years but as acreages are small there is much unmechanised work.
